learning_outcomes.description: Demonstrate knowledge of the importance of understanding human development for direct practice.
Demonstrate knowledge of a variety of theories of human development.
Demonstrate knowledge of the values and assumptions that underpin the study of human development.
Demonstrate advanced knowledge of the major features, events, processes and contexts of human development.
Understand the many contextual factors that impact on human development.
Demonstrate an enhanced understanding of the relationships between various theories and models of human development.
Demonstrate skills in understanding and critically assessing challenges and problems within a human development framework.

assessments.task_description:
This in-class/in-person quiz is an initial task to assess your knowledge of the course material you studied during Weeks 1 to 3 of this course, that is:

  1. the relevance of understanding human development across the lifespan for social work practice;
  2. Harms’ (2021) multidimensional approach to human development; and
  3. the idea of reflectively and reflexively locating yourself in relation to the contents covered in this course. Your quiz is designed as a closed-book assessment and will contain 40 multiple-choice questions worth 0.5 marks each. The quiz is scheduled for Tuesday 19th August 2024 at 2pm, and will need to be completed within 50 minutes. As this quiz is taken in-class/in-person via Inspera, you must attend the lecture period during which it is scheduled to be able to complete this task. You must bring your Student ID card with you to verify your identity.

Note: This assessment task must be completed via Inspera, in person. Inspera Assessment is an online assessment tool used in courses at UQ. Inspera is cloud-based, works with a device with an up-to-date browser, and caches your responses so that you will not lose your assessment if you experience internet instability. Prior to the day of the In-Class Quiz ensure you visit this page and follow the links to familiarise yourself with the system and prepare for its use.

The use of generative Artificial Intelligence (AI) tools will not be permitted. Any attempted use of Generative AI may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.
assessments.submission_guidelines: You may be able to defer this exam.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You may be able to defer this exam.
assessments.late_submission: A penalty of 10% of the maximum possible mark will be deducted per 24 hours from time submission is due for up to 7 days. After 7 days, you will receive a mark of 0.
assessments.additional_info: You may be able to defer this exam.

assessments.due_date:
PowerPoint slides are due in Week 9 on Friday.

26/09/2025 1:00 pm

Presentations will occur in Week 10, conducted in person. Some presentations may be scheduled outside of regular tutorial times.

8/10/2025 -10/10/2025
assessments.task_description:
This description is only a summary of the task. For full details, including the marking rubric, please refer to the course Learn UQ (Blackboard) site.

In Week 4, students will be allocated to groups for their second assessment task: Group presentation (In-class) – Case analysis. The relevant case study will be published at the start of Week 5. PowerPoint slides are due at the end of Week 9, and presentations will occur in Week 10, conducted in person from 8th – 10th October, some presentations may be scheduled outside of regular tutorial times. 

The purpose of your conversation is to:

  1. Analyse the case study provided, taking into consideration the main character's developmental tasks and transitions across their lifespan; their current level of functioning, including both strengths and difficulties; and sources of risk, adversity, and resilience in their life.
  2. Consider ways of supporting the main character in coping with past and current adversities, risks, and difficulties, promoting their strengths, and enhancing their resilience

This task requires students to work in groups of three to four to prepare and present a professional conversation about the case study provided. The conversation will be maximally 7.5 minutes per group member, that is, a total of maximally 22.5 minutes for a group of three students and 30 minutes for a group of four. Your presentation will be supported with PowerPoint slides, to which all members are expected to contribute. 

Note: This task has been designed to be challenging, authentic and complex. Whilst students may use AI and/or MT technologies, successful completion of assessment in this course will require students to critically engage in specific contexts and tasks for which artificial intelligence will provide only limited support and guidance. A failure to reference generative AI or MT use may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct. To pass this assessment, students will be required to demonstrate detailed comprehension of their written submission independent of AI and MT tools.
assessments.submission_guidelines: This assessment requires students to submit an electronic version of their assignment via Blackboard. The electronic version of your assignment will be submitted via Blackboard, using the Turnitin software.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You may be able to apply for an extension.
assessments.late_submission: A penalty of 10% of the maximum possible mark will be deducted per 24 hours from time submission is due for up to 7 days. After 7 days, you will receive a mark of 0.
assessments.additional_info: You may be able to apply for an extension.

assessments.task_description:
This final assessment task (Exam - Quiz and Case Analysis) is a closed-book assessment of 120 minutes (plus 10 minutes of reading time). It is an opportunity for you to demonstrate your knowledge and understanding of human development as a multidimensional process and to show how it may inform social work’s contribution to enhancing human wellbeing in line with “[p]rinciples of social justice, human rights, collective responsibility, and respect for diversity” (IFSW/IASSW 2014).

To this end, your end-of-semester exam will be based on a case study, provided in Week 12, and require you to answer 20 multiple choice questions, a set of four short-answer questions and one short essay question which together will –  

  1. Test your knowledge of relevant theories (and/or models and/or approaches) and concepts covered during this semester and your application of these theories (and/or models and/or approaches) and concepts to the case study provided, to analyse the specified character's current situation (that is, at the point of seeking social work support). 
  2. Your analysis should take into consideration factors that have impacted the character's development through the stages of lifespan development covered in Weeks 8 to 13. This entails attention to the character's developmental tasks and transitions during these stages, highlighting both sources of risk, adversity, and resilience, as well as strengths and difficulties displayed.
  3. Based on the analysis conducted, propose interventions to support the main character in coping with past and current adversities, risks and difficulties, promote their strengths, and enhance their resilience. 

Additional Information

Students are permitted to prepare and bring ONE (1) page of handwritten notes into the exam.

This means: There cannot be anything written on the back of the page, and the notes must not be typed. 

The examination supervisor will check every student’s notes. Anyone, who has more than the one permitted page or whose notes are typed up (printed) rather than handwritten, will have their notes confiscated, and the matter will be treated as potential misconduct. 

Note: This assessment task must be completed in person. The use of generative Artificial Intelligence (AI) tools will not be permitted. Any attempted use of Generative AI may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.
assessments.submission_guidelines: You may be able to defer this exam.

learning_activities.topic:
Week 1 Lecture: Introduction - A Multidimension Approach to Lifespan Development

This introductory lecture provides the foundation for the contents covered in the remainder of the semester. It comprises two parts:

  1. An overview of the course and its relevance to social work practice, including a discussion of the structure, content and assessment in the course.
  2. An introduction to Harms' (2021) multidimensional approach to human development as an overarching framework to locate, critique, and apply the theories and debates covered in this course.

Reading: Harms (2021) Chapter 1

Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L03
learning_activities.topic_title: Week 1 Lecture: Introduction - A Multidimension Approach to Lifespan Development
learning_activities.topic_description: Week 1 Lecture: Introduction - A Multidimension Approach to Lifespan Development This introductory lecture provides the foundation for the contents covered in the remainder of the semester. It comprises two parts: An overview of the course and its relevance to social work practice, including a discussion of the structure, content and assessment in the course. An introduction to Harms' (2021) multidimensional approach to human development as an overarching framework to locate, critique, and apply the theories and debates covered in this course. Reading: Harms (2021) Chapter 1

learning_activities.topic:
Week 2 Lecture: Development in Relational Contexts

In this lecture, we continue to explore Harms' (2021) multidimensional approach, focusing on the relational and social dimensions of human development.

Reading: Harms (2021) Chapter 2

Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L03

learning_activities.topic:
Week 5 Lecture: Pre-birth and Infancy

This lecture explores the first stage of human development, the antenatal stage through to birth. We then examine development in infancy with an overview of physical, neurobiological, cognitive, social, emotional, and personality development. Our theory in focus this week is attachment theory.

Reading: Harms (2021) Chapter 4

Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L03, L04, L05, L06
learning_activities.topic_description: Week 5 Lecture: Pre-birth and Infancy This lecture explores the first stage of human development, the antenatal stage through to birth. We then examine development in infancy with an overview of physical, neurobiological, cognitive, social, emotional, and personality development. Our theory in focus this week is attachment theory. Reading: Harms (2021) Chapter 4

learning_activities.topic:
Week 6 Lecture: Development in Early Childhood

This lecture focuses on the developmental tasks and transitions in early childhood, as well as key sources of risk, adversity, and resilience during this stage of the lifespan. Our theory in focus is Piaget's theory of cognitive development.

Reading: Harms (2021) Chapter 5

Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L03, L04, L05, L06

learning_activities.topic:
Week 7 Lecture: Development in Middle Childhood

This week, we examine the developmental tasks and transitions in middle childhood, as well as key sources of risk, adversity, and resilience during this stage of the lifespan. Theory in focus this week: Vygotsky's sociocultural theory of cognitive development.

Reading: Harms (2021) Chapter 6

Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L03, L04, L05, L06

learning_activities.topic:
Week 8 Lecture: From Adolescence to Emerging Adulthood

This week, we examine the developmental tasks and transitions in adolescence, as well as key sources of risk, adversity, and resilience during this stage of the lifespan. Theory in focus: Arnett's theory of emerging adulthood. We will consider this recently proposed stage of emerging adulthood - what does it entail, and how does it compare to adolescence? 

Readings: Harms (2021) Chapter 7; Arnett et al. (2019) Chapter 9

Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L03, L04, L05, L06
learning_activities.topic_title: Week 8 Lecture: From Adolescence to Emerging Adulthood

learning_activities.topic:
Week 9 Lecture: From Emerging to Young Adulthood

We examine the developmental tasks and transitions in early adulthood, as well as key sources of risk, adversity, and resilience during this stage of the lifespan. We ask: How does it compare to the recently proposed stage of emerging adulthood?

Reading: Harms (2021), Chapter 8; Arnett et al. (2019) Chapter 9

Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L03, L04, L05, L06

learning_activities.topic:
Week 12 Lecture: Social Work at the End of Life

While grief and loss are themes that pervade all social work practice, at the end of the semester, we want to consider the relevance of these themes for the end of life and for those left behind.

Reading: Harms (2021) Chapters 11 & 12

Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L03, L04, L05, L06
